comment._content: Does anyone know who is represented in the paintings on either side of the mirror and the bust in the corner?

comment.author: 23222653@N00
comment._content: To the right of the mirror is Samuel Osgood — I checked out 'all sizes' and saw his initial and surname and hit up Wikipedia. Can't read the other painting, but is the bust of Wm McKinley?

comment.author: 46869727@N00
comment._content: Hard to tell but should be a member of Washington's cabinet, or Pres Washington himself. www.senate.gov/vtour/4high.htm ublib.buffalo.edu/libraries/e-resources/ebooks/records/83...

comment._content: Very cool digs. I like the furniture here.

comment._content: Must be Edmund Randolph, first Attorney General. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edmund_Randolph

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: All above: "A surfeit of erudition". This is what makes Flickr + LOC = great. There is also an alternative view of the room here: www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2764618489/

comment.author: 36899742@N00
comment._content: Can't you just see the colors here? Mahogany wood, deep red or maroon leather, red oriental rug, gold ornamentation. I did a little editing on the photo ... lightened it, increased contrast, removed salt and pepper noise. You can clearly see "McKinley" below the bust: As for Randolph, you can just about make out the word "General" above his portrait. I imagine "Attorney" or "Atty" is in the shadows:

comment.author: 36899742@N00
comment._content: Some more links: www.senate.gov/artandhistory/art/resources/pdf/President_... I love this quote: “Gilding, frescoes, arabesques, glitter and glow above and around. There is not one quiet hue on which the tired sight may rest. Gazing, I feel an indescribable desire to pluck a few of Signor Brumidi’s red legged babies and pug-nosed cupids from their precarious perches on the lofty ceilings, to commit them to nurses or to anybody who will smooth out their rumpled little legs and make them look comfortable.” Interestingly, in 1917, Wilson was inaugurated privately in this room on March 4, then publicly in front of the capitol on March 5th. Probably because March 4th was a Sunday. memory.loc.gov/ammem/pihtml/pioaths.html

comment.author: 47022252@N00
comment._content:
I just check back after asking my innocent question. I am thoroughly amazed by the amount of information and passion.

Thank you to everyone!
